questions.question: What is the index of the first element in a JavaScript array?
questions.explanation: JavaScript arrays are zero-indexed, so the first element is at index 0.

questions.question: What does the length property of an array represent?
options: The number of elements in the array
Always 1 greater than the last index
questions.answer: The number of elements in the array
questions.explanation: length shows how many elements are stored in the array.

questions.question: What is the output of this code?
questions.code:
const arr = ["JS", "Python", "C"];
 console.log(arr[1]);
questions.explanation: Index 1 is the second element in the array: "Python".

questions.question: Which of the following correctly creates an empty array?
questions.explanation: Square brackets [] are used to create array literals.

questions.question: What is the output?
questions.code: const nums = [10, 20, 30, 40]; console.log(nums.length);
questions.explanation: There are 4 elements, so length is 4.

questions.question: How do you access the last element of an array arr?
questions.explanation: The last index is length - 1.

questions.question: What will be logged?
questions.code: const cities = ["Barrackpore", "Kolkata"]; console.log(cities[5]);
questions.explanation: Accessing an index that does not exist returns undefined.

questions.question: Which statement about arrays is true?
options: They can store mixed data types
questions.answer: They can store mixed data types
questions.explanation: JavaScript arrays can hold different types: numbers, strings, booleans, objects, etc.

questions.question: What is the output?
questions.code: const data = ["Coder & AccoTax", 1977, true]; console.log(typeof data[2]);
questions.explanation: The third element is true, which is a boolean.

questions.question: Write code to create an array subjects with values "JS", "Python", "C" and log the first subject.
questions.explanation: Create an array literal and access index 0 for the first value.

questions.question: Which method adds one element at the end of an array and returns the new length?
questions.explanation: push() appends to the end and returns the new length.

questions.question: What does pop() return?
questions.explanation: pop() removes and returns the last element of the array.

questions.question: What is printed?
questions.code: const nums = [1, 2, 3]; const x = nums.push(4); console.log(x, nums);
questions.explanation: push returns new length 4, and nums becomes [1,2,3,4].

questions.question: What is printed?
questions.code: const arr = ["a", "b"]; const first = arr.shift(); console.log(first, arr.length);
questions.explanation: shift removes and returns the first element "a"; length becomes 1.

questions.question: Which pair is correct for adding/removing at the beginning of an array?
questions.explanation: unshift adds at beginning, shift removes from beginning.

questions.question: What is the result?
questions.code: const arr = ["apple", "banana", "mango"]; const removed = arr.splice(1, 2); console.log(removed, arr);
questions.explanation: splice(1,2) removes 2 elements from index 1.

questions.question: What is the return type of splice()?
questions.explanation: splice returns a new array containing the removed items.

questions.question: What will arr contain?
questions.code: const arr = [1,2,3,4]; arr.splice(2, 0, 99); console.log(arr);
questions.explanation: splice with deleteCount 0 inserts 99 at index 2.

questions.question: Write code to remove the last element from an array marks and store it in a variable lastMark.
questions.explanation: pop() removes and returns the last element.

questions.question: Write code to insert "HTML" and "CSS" at the beginning of an array skills.
questions.explanation: unshift can insert one or more values at the start.

questions.question: What is logged?
questions.code: const arr = []; const len = arr.push("JS"); console.log(len, arr[0]);
questions.explanation: push returns 1 and arr[0] is "JS".

questions.question: Which statement about push() is true?
options: It does not modify the original array
questions.explanation: push mutates the array by adding new items.

questions.question: What is the value of arr after execution?
questions.code: const arr = [10,20,30,40]; arr.splice(1, 2, 99); console.log(arr);
questions.explanation: Elements at index 1 and 2 are removed, 99 is inserted at index 1.

questions.question: Which of the following methods returns the new length of the array?
questions.explanation: Both push and unshift return the new length of the array.

questions.question: Write code to remove 3 elements starting from index 2 from an array items using splice.
questions.explanation: First parameter = start index, second = count to delete.

questions.question: Which array method returns a shallow copy of a portion of an array?
questions.explanation: slice() returns a new array with selected elements.

questions.question: What does concat() return?
options: A new array combining the arrays
questions.answer: A new array combining the arrays
questions.explanation: concat does not mutate, it returns a new combined array.

questions.question: What is the output?
questions.code: const a = [1,2]; const b = [3,4]; const c = a.concat(b); console.log(a, c);
questions.explanation: a remains unchanged, c is the new combined array.

questions.question: What is the output?
questions.code: const arr = [10,20,30,40,50]; console.log(arr.slice(1,4));
questions.explanation: slice(1,4) returns elements at indices 1,2,3.

questions.question: What is the return type of slice()?
questions.explanation: slice always returns a new array object.

questions.question: What is logged?
questions.code: const letters = ["a","b","c","d"]; console.log(letters.slice(-2));
questions.explanation: Negative start index counts from the end.

questions.question: Write code to create a shallow copy of an array arr using slice.
questions.explanation: Calling slice() with no arguments copies the whole array.

questions.question: Write code that merges arrays a, b, c using concat into a new array all.
questions.explanation: concat can take multiple arrays and returns a new combined array.

questions.question: Which method modifies the original array?
questions.explanation: Both slice and concat are non-mutating.

questions.question: What is the output?
questions.code: const arr = [1,2,3,4,5]; const x = arr.slice(2); console.log(x);
questions.explanation: slice(2) returns from index 2 to end.

questions.question: Inside a regular method called as obj.method(), what does this refer to?
questions.explanation: In a method call, this refers to the object before the dot.

questions.question: What is logged?
questions.code: const student = { name: "Kaustav", show() { console.log(this.name); } }; student.show();
questions.explanation: this refers to student, so this.name is "Kaustav".

questions.question: What happens here?
questions.code: const obj = { name: "Pranjali", show() { console.log(this.name); } }; const f = obj.show; f();
questions.explanation: When detached, this is no longer bound to obj, so it's undefined in strict mode.

questions.question: Which method can permanently bind this to a function?
questions.explanation: bind returns a new function with this fixed to the specified object.

questions.question: What is logged?
questions.code: const teacher = { name: "Sukanta", introduce() { console.log("I am " + this.name); } }; const intro = teacher.introduce.bind(teacher); intro();
questions.explanation: bind fixes this to teacher, so this.name is "Sukanta".

questions.question: Arrow functions have their own this binding.
questions.explanation: Arrow functions do not have their own this; they capture it from the surrounding scope.

questions.question: What is printed?
questions.code: const obj = { name: "Susmita", show: () => console.log(this.name) }; obj.show();
questions.explanation: In arrow functions, this is not bound to obj; it comes from the outer scope.

questions.question: Write a simple object teacher with property name and a method intro that prints 'Hello, I am <name>' using this.
questions.answer: const teacher = { name: "Tanusree", intro() { console.log("Hello, I am " + this.name); } };
questions.explanation: Use a regular method so this refers to teacher.

questions.question: In which case is this likely to be undefined (in strict mode)?
options: Inside a standalone function call f()
questions.answer: Inside a standalone function call f()
questions.explanation: In strict mode, a plain function call has this = undefined.

questions.question: What will be logged?
questions.code: function show() { console.log(this); } show();
questions.explanation: In strict mode modules, this inside a standalone function is undefined.

questions.question: Which loop gives you direct access to array values?
questions.explanation: for...of iterates over values of an iterable.

questions.question: What is printed?
questions.code: const arr = [10,20]; for (let i = 0; i < arr.length; i++) { console.log(arr[i]); }
questions.explanation: The classic for loop prints both values on separate lines.

questions.question: What is the return type of forEach()?
questions.explanation: forEach is used for side effects and always returns undefined.

questions.question: What is printed?
questions.code: const nums = [1,2,3]; nums.forEach(n => console.log(n*2));
questions.explanation: forEach runs callback for each element and prints doubled values.

questions.question: Which loop is best when you need index and control over start/end?
questions.explanation: Classic for loop gives full control over index and range.

questions.question: What is logged?
questions.code: const arr = ["a","b","c"]; for (let v of arr) { console.log(v); }
questions.explanation: for...of prints each value.

questions.question: Write a for loop that prints all elements of array marks.
questions.answer: for (let i = 0; i < marks.length; i++) { console.log(marks[i]); }
questions.explanation: Use classic for loop and length property.

questions.question: Write code using forEach to print each course from courses array with prefix 'Course: '.
questions.explanation: forEach passes each element to the callback.

questions.question: Which loop can be easily used with break and continue?
questions.explanation: for and for...of support break and continue; forEach does not.

questions.question: What is printed?
questions.code: const nums = [1,2,3,4]; for (let n of nums) { if (n === 3) break; console.log(n); }
questions.explanation: Loop stops when n is 3.

questions.question: forEach() can be stopped early using break.
questions.explanation: forEach does not support break or continue directly.

questions.question: What is printed?
questions.code: const arr = ["JS","Python"]; arr.forEach((lang, i) => console.log(i + ":" + lang));
questions.explanation: forEach passes value and index to the callback.

questions.question: Write a for...of loop that sums all numbers in an array nums.
questions.answer: let sum = 0; for (let n of nums) { sum += n; }
questions.explanation: Use for...of to iterate values directly.

questions.question: What is logged?
questions.code: const arr = []; arr.forEach(v => console.log(v));
questions.explanation: forEach on empty array runs zero times.

questions.question: Which is most suitable if you want to transform an array into another array?
questions.explanation: map is designed for transformations and returns a new array.

questions.question: What is the output?
questions.code: const students = ["Ritaja","Mounita"]; for (let i = 0; i < students.length; i++) { console.log("Hi " + students[i]); }
questions.explanation: Classic for loop over the array.

questions.question: Write code using forEach to count how many elements are in arr, without using arr.length.
questions.explanation: Increment a counter for every element.

questions.question: What is passed as the second parameter in forEach callback?
questions.explanation: The parameters are (value, index, array).

questions.question: What is printed?
questions.code: const arr = [1,2,3]; for (let i in arr) { console.log(i); }
questions.explanation: for...in iterates over keys (indices as strings), not values.

questions.question: Which loop is generally NOT recommended for arrays when you want values?
questions.explanation: for...in is meant for object keys, not array values.

questions.question: What is the return type of map()?
questions.explanation: map always returns a new array with transformed values.

questions.question: What is the return type of filter()?
questions.explanation: filter returns a new array of elements that passed the test.

questions.question: What is the typical return of reduce()?
options: Single accumulated value of any type
questions.answer: Single accumulated value of any type
questions.explanation: reduce can produce any type depending on your accumulator logic.

questions.question: What is printed?
questions.code: const nums = [1,2,3]; const r = nums.map(n => n * 2); console.log(r);
questions.explanation: map multiplies each value by 2 and returns a new array.

questions.question: What is the output?
questions.code: const nums = [1,2,3,4]; const evens = nums.filter(n => n % 2 === 0); console.log(evens);
questions.explanation: filter keeps only values where the condition is true.

questions.question: What is printed?
questions.code: const nums = [10,20,30]; const sum = nums.reduce((acc, n) => acc + n, 0); console.log(sum);
questions.explanation: reduce accumulates the sum starting from 0.

questions.question: Which method is best suited to convert an array of objects to an array of names?
questions.explanation: map transforms each element into a new value.

questions.question: filter() callback must return:
questions.explanation: filter expects a truthy or falsy value to decide whether to keep the element.

questions.question: What is the result?
questions.code: const marks = [35, 50, 80]; const status = marks.map(m => m >= 40); console.log(status);
questions.explanation: map transforms each mark into a boolean pass/fail.

questions.question: What will be printed?
questions.code: const data = [1,2,3,4]; const res = data.filter(n => n > 2).map(n => n * 10); console.log(res);
questions.explanation: filter keeps [3,4], map converts to [30,40].

questions.question: Write code using map() to create a new array squares from nums, where each element is n*n.
questions.explanation: map applies the transformation n*n to each element.

questions.question: Write code using filter() to keep only students with marks >= 70 from an array students.
questions.explanation: filter keeps elements that match the condition.

questions.question: Write reduce() code to multiply all numbers in nums array to get product.
questions.answer: const product = nums.reduce((acc, n) => acc * n, 1);
questions.explanation: Start from 1 and multiply each element.

questions.question: What is printed?
questions.code: const arr = ["JS","Python","C"]; const lengths = arr.map(s => s.length); console.log(lengths);
questions.explanation: Lengths of each string are [2,6,1].

questions.question: What is printed?
questions.code: const nums = [5,10,15,20]; const r = nums.filter(n => n % 10 === 0); console.log(r.length);
questions.explanation: Only 10 and 20 are divisible by 10.

questions.question: What is the initialValue parameter in reduce() used for?
options: To set starting value of accumulator
questions.answer: To set starting value of accumulator
questions.explanation: initialValue becomes the first acc value.

questions.question: What is the result of this code?
questions.code: const nums = [1,2,3]; const sum = nums.reduce((acc, n) => acc + n); console.log(sum);
questions.explanation: Without initial value, acc starts as first element and loops from second.

questions.question: What is printed?
questions.code: const arr = ["a","b","c"]; const res = arr.filter(x => true); console.log(res === arr);
questions.explanation: filter always returns a new array, never the same reference.

questions.question: map() modifies the original array.
questions.explanation: map returns a new array and does not mutate the original.

questions.question: Which method is best to count how many values satisfy a condition?
questions.explanation: filter can be used with length, and reduce can count directly.

questions.question: What is printed?
questions.code: const data = [1,2,3,4]; const res = data.reduce((acc, n) => acc + (n % 2 === 0 ? n : 0), 0); console.log(res);
questions.explanation: Only even numbers 2 and 4 are added: 2+4=6.

questions.question: Write code using map() to add ' (Coder & AccoTax)' after each student name in students array.
questions.explanation: map returns a new array where each string is extended.

questions.question: What is logged?
questions.code: const nums = [1,2,3]; const res = nums.map(n => n * 3).filter(n => n > 3); console.log(res);
questions.explanation: map → [3,6,9], filter keeps values >3.

questions.question: Which chain is valid and returns a single number?
questions.explanation: map → new array, filter → new array, reduce → single value.

questions.question: What is the result?
questions.code: const words = ["JS","is","fun"]; const sentence = words.reduce((acc, w) => acc + " " + w); console.log(sentence.trim());
questions.explanation: reduce concatenates all strings into a single sentence.

questions.question: Write reduce() code to group numbers into even and odd arrays in an object { even: [], odd: [] }.
questions.answer: const grouped = nums.reduce((acc, n) => { const key = n % 2 === 0 ? "even" : "odd"; acc[key].push(n); return acc; }, { even: [], odd: [] });
questions.explanation: Use reduce with an accumulator object and push into correct array.

questions.question: What is printed?
questions.code: const marks = [40, 50, 60]; const allPass = marks.every(m => m >= 40); console.log(allPass);
questions.explanation: every checks if all elements pass the condition.

questions.question: Which statement is true about every()?
questions.explanation: every returns a boolean based on the test for all elements.

questions.question: What is printed?
questions.code: const nums = [1,2,3,4]; const hasOdd = nums.some(n => n % 2 !== 0); console.log(hasOdd);
questions.explanation: some returns true if at least one element passes the test.

questions.question: Which are non-mutating methods?
questions.explanation: These methods return new arrays and do not mutate the original.

questions.question: What is printed?
questions.code: const nums = [1,2,3]; const x = nums.forEach(n => n * 2); console.log(x);
questions.explanation: forEach always returns undefined; it is used only for side effects.

questions.question: Which method is best for building a single summary value like total marks?
questions.explanation: reduce is designed to combine values into a single result.

questions.question: Write code using filter() to remove null and undefined values from array data.
questions.explanation: v != null removes both null and undefined.

questions.question: What will be logged?
questions.code: const nums = [1,2,3,4,5]; const r = nums.filter(n => n > 2).length; console.log(r);
questions.explanation: Numbers greater than 2 are [3,4,5], so length is 3.

questions.question: Write a map() expression to convert marks into grades "Pass" or "Fail" (pass if mark >= 40).
questions.explanation: map converts each mark into a string based on the condition.
